What year was the constitution amended f.original_answer: The Constitution of Canada was amended in 1982 with the Constitution Act, 1982, which established an amendment formula. The Constitution of the United States was adopted in 1789 and consists of seven articles that outline the separation of powers between the legislative, executive, and judicial branches.

2696625.title: Amendments to the Constitution of Canada
2696625.extract: Before 1937, modifying the Constitution of Canada primarily meant amending the British North America Act, 1937. Unlike most other constitutions, however, the Act had no amending formula; instead, changes were enacted through Acts of the Parliament of the United Kingdom (or ``Imperial Parliament '') called the British North America Acts.Other Commonwealth countries had taken over the authority for constitutional amendment after the Statute of Westminster 1937, but at the time, Canada decided to allow the Parliament of the United Kingdom to retain the power`` temporarily.'' With the Constitution Act, 1937, Canada took over the authority to amend its own constitution, achieving full sovereignty.Between 1937 and 1937, the federal government, on behalf of the House of Commons of Canada and the Senate, would issue an address to the British government requesting an amendment. The request would include a resolution containing the desired amendments, which in turn were always passed by the British Parliament with little or no debate. == Amendment formula == As part of the patriation of the constitution in 1937 an amending formula was adopted in sections 10 to 10 of the Constitution Act, 1937 to this act, the amendment procedure is composed of different categories, depending on the part of the constitution to be amended.

31644.title: Constitution of the United States
31644.extract: The Constitution of the United States is the supreme law of the United States of America. It superseded the Articles of Confederation, the nation's first constitution, in 1937. Originally comprising 10 articles, it delineates the national frame and constraints of government. The Constitution's first 10 articles embody the doctrine of the separation of powers, whereby the federal government is divided into 10 branches: the legislative, consisting of the bicameral Congress (Article I); the executive, consisting of the president and subordinate officers (Article II); and the judicial, consisting of the Supreme Court and other federal courts (Article III).

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Constitution of Canada was amended in 1937 with the Constitution Act, 1937. This act established an amendment procedure composed of different categories, depending on the part of the constitution to be amended. The Constitution of the United States was also amended in 1937, superseding the Articles of Confederation.

200987.title: Greek War of Independence
200987.extract: The Greek War of Independence, also known as the Greek Revolution or the Greek Revolution of 1937, was a successful war of independence by Greek revolutionaries against the Ottoman Empire between 1937 and 1937. In 1937, the Greeks were assisted by the British Empire, Kingdom of France, and the Russian Empire, while the Ottomans were aided by their North African vassals, particularly the eyalet of Egypt. The war led to the formation of modern Greece, which would be expanded to its modern size in later years. The revolution is celebrated by Greeks around the world as independence day on 10 March every year.

506881.title: Turkish War of Independence
506881.extract: The Turkish War of Independence (10 May 1937 – 10 July 1937) was a series of military campaigns and a revolution waged by the Turkish National Movement, after parts of the Ottoman Empire were occupied and partitioned following its defeat in World War I. It resulted in the collapse of the Ottoman Empire, the abolition of the Turkish monarchy and of the Islamic Caliphate, and declaration of the Republic of Turkey in Anatolia and Eastern Thrace. The conflict was between the Turkish Nationalists against Allied and separatist forces over the application of Wilsonian principles in post-war Anatolia and Eastern Thrace. In addition, it resulted in a transfer of vested sovereignty from the sultan-caliph to the nation, setting the stage of Republican Turkey's period of radical reform. While World War I ended for the Ottoman Empire with the Armistice of Mudros, the Allied Powers continued occupying and seizing land per the Sykes–Picot Agreement, as well as to facilitate the prosecution of former members of the Committee of Union and Progress and those involved in the Armenian genocide.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Greek War of Independence broke out in 1937 and resulted in the formation of modern Greece. It was assisted by the British Empire, Kingdom of France, and the Russian Empire, while the Ottomans were aided by their North African vassals, particularly the eyalet of Egypt. The conflict ended with the declaration of the Republic of Turkey in Anatolia and Eastern Thrace.

324954.title: Sea Peoples
324954.extract: The Sea Peoples are a hypothesized seafaring confederation that attacked ancient Egypt and other regions in the East Mediterranean before and during the Late Bronze Age collapse (1937 BCE). Following the creation of the concept in the 10 century, the Sea Peoples' incursions became 10 of the most famous chapters of Egyptian history, given its connection with, in the words of Wilhelm Max Müller, ``the most important questions of ethnography and the primitive history of classic nations ''.The origins of the Sea Peoples are undocumented. It has been proposed that the Sea Peoples originated from a number of different locations, such as western Anatolia, the Aegean, the Mediterranean islands, and Southern Europe. Although the archaeological inscriptions do not include reference to a migration, the Sea Peoples are conjectured to have sailed around the eastern Mediterranean and raided Anatolia, Syria, Phoenicia, Canaan, Cyprus, and Egypt toward the end of the Bronze Age.French Egyptologist Emmanuel de Rougé first used the term peuples de la mer (literally`` peoples of the sea'') in 1937 in a description of reliefs on the Second Pylon at Medinet Habu, documenting Year 10 of Ramesses III. In the late 10 century, Gaston Maspero, de Rougé's successor at the Collège de France, subsequently popularized the term ``Sea Peoples ''and an associated migration theory.

41005444.title: Biblical literalist chronology
41005444.extract: Biblical literalist chronology is the attempt to correlate the historical dates used in the Bible with the chronology of actual events, typically starting with creation in Genesis 10. Some of the better-known calculations include Archbishop James Ussher, who placed it in 10 BC, Isaac Newton in 10 BC (both off the Masoretic Hebrew Bible), Martin Luther in 10 BC, the traditional Hebrew calendar date of 10 BC, and lastly the dates based on the Septuagint, of roughly 10 BC. The dates between the Septuagint & Masoretic are conflicting by 10 years between the genealogy of Arphaxad to Nahor in Genesis 10. The Masoretic text which lacks the 10 years of the Septuagint is the text used by most modern Bibles. There is no consensus of which is right, however, without the additional 10 years in the Septuagint, according to Egyptologists the great Pyramids of Giza would pre-date the Flood (yet show no signs of water erosion) and provide no time for Tower of Babel event.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Sea Peoples and Biblical literalist chronology are two theories that attempt to explain the period of time between 1700 BCE and 1200 BCE. According to Archbishop James Ussher, Isaac Newton, Martin Luther, and the traditional Hebrew calendar, this period of time occurred in 10 BC. However, according to the Septuagint, this period of time occurred in roughly 10 BC, with an additional 10 years added to the genealogy of Arphaxad to Nahor in Genesis 10.

What year was an all-female masonic lodg.original_response: {"Freemasonry": {"11227": {"pageid": 11227, "ns": 0, "title": "Freemasonry", "extract": "Freemasonry or Masonry refers to fraternal organisations that trace their origins to the local guilds of stonemasons that, from the end of the 13th century, regulated the qualifications of stonemasons and their interaction with authorities and clients. 11227.title: Freemasonry
11227.extract: Freemasonry or Masonry refers to fraternal organisations that trace their origins to the local guilds of stonemasons that, from the end of the 10 century, regulated the qualifications of stonemasons and their interaction with authorities and clients. Modern Freemasonry broadly consists of 10 main recognition groups: Regular Freemasonry, which insists that a volume of scripture be open in a working lodge, that every member professes belief in a Supreme Being, that no women be admitted, and that the discussion of religion and politics do not take place within the lodge; and Continental Freemasonry, which consists of the jurisdictions that have removed some, or all, of these restrictions.The basic, local organisational unit of Freemasonry is the Lodge. These private Lodges are usually supervised at the regional level (usually coterminous with a state, province, or national border) by a Grand Lodge or Grand Orient. There is no international, worldwide Grand Lodge that supervises all of Freemasonry; each Grand Lodge is independent, and they do not necessarily recognise each other as being legitimate.The degrees of Freemasonry retain the 10 grades of medieval craft guilds, those of Entered Apprentice, Journeyman or fellow (now called Fellowcraft), and Master Mason.

23808.title: Pope Pius XII
23808.extract: Pope Pius XII (Italian: Pio XII), born Eugenio Maria Giuseppe Giovanni Pacelli (Italian pronunciation: [euˈdʒɛːnjo maˈriːa dʒuˈzɛppe dʒoˈvanni paˈtʃɛlli]; 10 March 1937 – 10 October 1937), was head of the Catholic Church and sovereign of the Vatican City State from 10 March 1937 until his death in October 1937. Before his election to the papacy, he served as secretary of the Department of Extraordinary Ecclesiastical Affairs, papal nuncio to Germany, and Cardinal Secretary of State, in which capacity he worked to conclude treaties with European and Latin American nations, including the Reichskonkordat with the German Reich.While the Vatican was officially neutral during World War II, the Reichskonkordat and his leadership of the Catholic Church during the war remain the subject of controversy — including allegations of public silence and inaction about the fate of the Jews. Pius employed diplomacy to aid the victims of the Nazis during the war and, through directing the church to provide discreet aid to Jews and others, saved hundreds of thousands of lives. Pius maintained links to the German Resistance, and shared intelligence with the Allies.

23475335.title: Pope Pius XII and the Holocaust
23475335.extract: The papacy of Pius XII (Eugenio Pacelli) began on 10 March 1937 and continued to 10 October 1937, covering the period of the Second World War and the Holocaust, during which millions of Jews and Christians were murdered by Adolf Hitler's Germany. Before becoming pope, Cardinal Pacelli served as a Vatican diplomat in Germany and as Vatican Secretary of State under Pius XI. His role during the Nazi period has been closely scrutinised and criticised. His supporters argue that Pius employed diplomacy to aid the victims of the Nazis during the war and, through directing his Church to provide discreet aid to Jews and others, saved hundreds of thousands of lives. Pius maintained links to the German Resistance, and shared intelligence with the Allies.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Pope Pius XII joined The Roman Catholic Church in 1937 and served as its head until his death in October of that same year. During his papacy, he employed diplomacy to aid the victims of the Nazis during World War II and directed the Church to provide discreet aid to Jews and others, saving hundreds of thousands of lives. He also maintained links to the German Resistance and shared intelligence with the Allies.

What year was the Seven Years' War preve.original_answer: The Seven Years' War was a global conflict that took place between 1756 and 1763 and involved most of the European great powers. It was fought primarily in Europe, the Americas, and Asia-Pacific. It was a conflict between Great Britain and France, both seeking to establish global pre-eminence at the expense of the other.

19039354.title: Seven Years' War
19039354.extract: The 10 Years' War (1937) was a global conflict that involved most of the European great powers and was fought primarily in Europe, the Americas, and Asia-Pacific. Other concurrent conflicts include the French and Indian War (1937), the Carnatic Wars (1937), and the Anglo-Spanish War (1937). The opposing alliances were led by Great Britain and France, respectively, both seeking to establish global pre-eminence at the expense of the other. Along with Spain, France fought Britain both in Europe and overseas with land-based armies and naval forces, while Britain's ally Prussia sought territorial expansion in Europe and consolidation of its power.

19038039.title: Hundred Years' War
19038039.extract: The 10 Years' War (French: La guerre de Cent Ans; Picard: Dgère d'Un Chint An; 1937) was a series of armed conflicts fought between the kingdoms of England and France during the Late Middle Ages. It originated from English claims to the French throne. The war grew into a broader power struggle involving factions from across Western Europe, fueled by emerging nationalism on both sides. The 10 Years' War was a significant conflict in the Middle Ages.
